abstracts.cdata!:
This request for inspection comes from
            landowners who seek the assistance of the Inspection Panel
            because they have lost their land and forests during the
            currency of the Governance Promotion Adjustment Loan by the
            World Bank to Papua New Guinea.  The Requesters claim that
            the Papua New Guinea government and logging industry
            participants failed to fulfill or demonstrate good faith on
            conditionalitys aimed at improving forest governance,
            imposed by the Bank on the Structural Adjustment Programme
            Loan (SAL.) The Requesters claim that the submission deals
            with significant instances of social, cultural, ecological
            and economic harm and that the disbursement of the second
            tranche without requiring a full review of the contractual
            provisions of the loan constitutes a violation of the
            contractual provisions of the SAL by loaning to a borrower
            defaults to implement its own promises.  Examples set out in
            the claim indicating the development objectives of the
            governance loan have not been met and are unlikely to be
            met, if the disbursement of the second tranche is completed.
            The Requesters ask the Inspection Panel to address the need
            that arises from this claim. The Requesters ask that there
            be a moratorium on new concessions in the forests of Papua
            New Guinea to allow a respite for reform, that landowners be
            compensated for their losses, and the institutional reform
            processes put in place firmly.
